An alternating-possession throw-in ends when the throw-in ends, as in Rule 4-42-5.
The opportunity to make an alternating-possession throw-in is lost if the throw-in team violates.
If either team fouls during an alternating-possession throw-in, it does not cause the throw-in team to lose the possession arrow.
If the defensive team commits a violation during the throw-in, the possession arrow is not switched.
The ball shall be put in play by a throw-in under circumstances as outlined in Rules 6-4-1, 6-4-2, 6-4-4; Rules 7-1 through 7-6; Rule 8-5; and Rules 9-1 through 9-13.
The ball shall be put in play by placing it at the disposal of the free thrower before each free throw.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when a goal is made, as in Rule 5-1.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when it is apparent the free throw will not be successful on a free throw which is to be followed by another free throw.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when it is apparent the free throw will not be successful on a free throw which is to be followed by a throw-in.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when a held ball occurs, or the ball lodges between the backboard and ring or comes to rest on the flange.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when a player-control or team-control foul occurs.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when an official's whistle is blown.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when time expires for a quarter or extra period.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when a foul, other than player-control or team-control, occurs.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when a free-throw violation by the throwing team occurs, as in Rule 9-1.
The ball becomes dead, or remains dead, when a violation occurs, as in Rules 9-2 through 13.

The ball does not become dead until the try or tap for field goal ends, or until the airborne shooter returns to the floor, when Article 5, 6, or 7 occurs while a try or tap for a field goal is in flight.
The ball does not become dead until the try or tap for field goal ends, or until the airborne shooter returns to the floor, when Article 5 or 7 occurs while a try for a free throw is in flight.

The ball does not become dead until the try or tap for field goal ends, or until the airborne shooter returns to the floor, when Article 7 occurs by any opponent of a player who has started a try or tap for field goal before the foul occurred, provided time did not expire before the ball was in flight.
The trying motion shall be continuous and begins after the ball comes to rest in the player's hand(s) on a try or touches the hand(s) on a tap, and is completed when the ball is clearly in flight.
The trying motion may include arm, foot or body movements used by the player when throwing the ball at the player's basket.
If A1's try or tap for field goal is legally touched in flight, the goal counts if made, if the period/quarter ends before or after the legal touching.
If the touching is interference or goaltending by Team A, no points are scored.
If Team B violates, the points are awarded – either two or three depending on whether it was a two or three-point try or tap for field goal.
A player is out of bounds when the player touches the floor, or any object other than a player/person, on or outside a boundary.
For location/status of a player in the air, see Rule 4-35.
The ball is out of bounds when it touches or is touched by a player who is out of bounds.
The ball is out of bounds when it touches or is touched by any other person, the floor, or any object on or outside a boundary.
The ball is out of bounds when it touches or is touched by the supports or back of the backboard.
The ball is out of bounds when it touches or is touched by the ceiling, overhead equipment or supports.
The ball is out of bounds when it passes over a rectangular backboard.
The ball is caused to go out of bounds by the last player in bounds to touch it or be touched by it.
The ball is caused to go out of bounds unless the ball touches a player who is out of bounds prior to touching something out of bounds other than a player.
If the ball is out of bounds because of touching or being touched by a player who is on or outside a boundary line, such player causes it to go out.

If the ball goes out of bounds and was last touched simultaneously by two opponents, both of whom are inbounds or out of bounds, play shall be resumed by the team entitled to the alternating-possession throw-in at the spot out of bounds nearest to where the simultaneous violation occurred.

If the official is in doubt as to who last touched the ball or if the officials disagree, play shall be resumed by the team entitled to the alternating-possession throw-in at the spot out of bounds nearest to where the simultaneous violation occurred.
If the alternating-possession procedure has not been established, play shall be resumed by a jump ball between the two players involved in the center restraining circle.
The ball is awarded out of bounds after a violation, as in Rules 9-1 through 13.
The ball is awarded out of bounds after a free throw for a technical foul, or a flagrant or intentional personal foul, as in Rules 8-5-2 and 8-5-3.
The ball is awarded out of bounds after a field goal or a successful free throw for any other personal foul as in Rule 8-5-1 or an awarded goal, as in Rules 9-11 and 9-12.
The ball is awarded out of bounds when the ball becomes dead while a team is in control, provided no infraction or the end of a quarter/period is involved.
The ball is awarded out of bounds after a player-control or team-control foul.
The ball is awarded out of bounds after a common foul before the bonus rule is in effect.
The ball is awarded out of bounds after a held ball, as in Rule 4-25, after the alternating-possession procedure has been established.
When a team does not make a thrower available, after a time-out or the intermission between any quarter, the resumption-of-play procedure is used to prevent delay.
The administering official will sound the whistle to indicate play will resume.
The ball shall be put in play if Team A is ready or it shall be placed on the floor.
The throw-in count shall begin and if a violation occurs, the procedure will be repeated for Team B.
Following a violation by one team only, if that team continues to delay when authorized to make a throw-in, it is a technical foul.
Following a violation by both teams, any further delay by either team is a technical foul.
After an out-of-bounds violation in either the frontcourt or the backcourt by either team, the throw-in shall be at the designated spot nearest to where the ball went out of bounds.

After a violation by either team, a foul by either team before the bonus is in effect or any other stoppage in play, the throw-in location will be determined by the location of the violation/foul or the location of the ball when the stoppage occurs.
If the throw-in is to be in the team's frontcourt, it shall be at either the nearest 28-foot mark along each sideline or the nearest spot 3-feet outside the lane line along the end line.
If the throw-in is to be in the team's backcourt, the throw-in shall be at the designated spot nearest to where the foul, violation or other stoppage in play occurred.

Officials shall determine the designated spot by using an imaginary line drawn from the intersection of the end line with the sideline to each lane line where it intersects with the free-throw line including the semicircle.
If the stoppage of play occurs inside the imaginary line, the designated spot shall be the nearest point on the end line 3-feet outside the lane line.
If the stoppage occurs outside the imaginary line, the designated spot shall be the nearest sideline at the 28-foot line.
Designated out-of-bounds spot throw-in behind the backboard shall be made from the nearer free-throw lane line extended.
Designated out-of-bounds spot throw-in at the division line opposite the scorer's and timer's table shall occur after a technical foul, as in Rule 4-19-5.
Any player of the team to whom the free throws have been awarded shall make the throw-in after a technical foul.
For an alternating-possession throw-in to start the second, third and fourth quarters, any player from the team with the possession arrow shall make the throw-in.

A throw-in anywhere along the end line after a goal or an awarded goal for basket interference or goaltending by a defensive player shall be made from the end of the court where the goal was made and from any point outside the end line.

The team not credited with the score shall make a throw-in from the end of the court where the goal was made and from any point outside the end line after a goal or an awarded goal for basket interference or goaltending by a defensive player.
Any player of the team may make a direct throw-in or may pass the ball along the end line to a teammate(s) outside the boundary.

A team retains the privilege of a throw-in if the scoring team commits a violation or common foul before the throw-in ends and before the bonus rule is in effect and the ensuing throw-in spot would have been on the end line.
The official shall hand or bounce the ball to the thrower for a throw-in unless the throw-in is from outside an end line following a successful goal.
The throw-in begins when the ball is at the disposal of a player of the team entitled to the throw-in.
The thrower shall release the ball on a pass directly into the court, except as in Rule 7-5-7, within five seconds after the throw-in begins.
The throw-in pass shall touch another player (inbounds or out of bounds) on the court before going out of bounds untouched.
The throw-in pass shall not touch a teammate while it is on the out-of-bounds side of the throw-in boundary plane.
The thrower shall not leave the designated throw-in spot until the ball has been released on a throw-in pass.
The opponent(s) of the thrower shall not have any body part through the inbounds side of the throw-in boundary plane until the ball has been released on a throw-in pass.
The thrower shall have a minimum of 3 feet horizontally from the opponent(s) as in Rule 1-2-2.
If the court is not marked accordingly, an imaginary restraining line shall be imposed by the administering official.
Teammates shall not occupy adjacent positions which are parallel to and within 3 feet of the boundary line if an opponent desires one of the positions.
The 3-foot restraining line is sometimes the temporary boundary line as in Rule 1-2-2.
When an official administers a throw-in to the wrong team, the mistake shall be rectified before the first dead ball after the ball becomes live unless there has been a change of possession.
When a free throw is awarded, the ball shall be placed at the disposal of the free thrower by the administering official.
The ball shall be bounced by the administering official.
The free throw count shall begin when the ball is placed at the disposal of the free thrower.
Either or both teams may be charged with a violation during the free throw process.
Following a time-out or intermission, the resumption-of-play procedure may be used to prevent delay.
The administering official shall sound the whistle to indicate play will resume.
The ball shall be placed at the disposal of the thrower or placed on the floor at the free-throw line.
The count shall begin when the ball is placed at the disposal of the thrower or on the floor at the free-throw line.
Either or both teams may be charged with a violation following the resumption of play.
If the offending team(s) continues to delay after a violation, a team technical foul shall be ruled.
If the ball is to become dead when the last free throw for a specific penalty is not successful, players shall not occupy any spaces along the free-throw lane lines.
During a free throw, lane spaces may be occupied as follows:
Marked lane spaces may be occupied by a maximum of two offensive players.
Four defensive players may occupy lane spaces during a free throw.
The first marked lane spaces on each side of the lane shall be occupied by opponents of the free thrower.
No teammate of the free thrower shall occupy either of the first marked lane spaces.
The second marked lane spaces on each side may be occupied by teammates of the free thrower.
The third marked lane spaces on each side, nearest the free thrower, may be occupied by the opponents of the free thrower.
Players shall be permitted to move along and across the lane to occupy a vacant marked lane space within the limitations listed in this rule.
Not more than one player may occupy any part of a marked lane space during a free throw.
Any player, other than the free thrower, who does not occupy a marked lane space shall be behind the free-throw line extended and behind the three-point line.
The free throw(s) awarded because of a personal foul shall be attempted by the offended player.
If the offended player withdraws because of an injury or disqualification, the offended player's substitute shall attempt the throw(s).
If no substitute is available, any teammate may attempt the throw(s) as selected by the team captain or head coach.
The free throws awarded because of a technical foul may be attempted by any player of the offended team.
The free throw(s) may include an eligible substitute or designated starter.
The coach or captain shall designate the free thrower(s) for technical fouls.
The try for goal shall be made within 10 seconds after the ball has been placed at the disposal of the free thrower at the free-throw line.
This 10-second limit shall apply to each free throw.
After a free throw which is not followed by another free throw, the ball shall be put in play by a throw-in.
If the try is for a personal foul other than intentional or flagrant, and is successful, the ball shall be put in play as after a field goal.

If the free throw is for a technical foul, the ball shall be put in play by any player of the free-thrower's team from out of bounds at the division line on the side opposite the scorer's and timer's table.
If the free throw is for an intentional personal foul or flagrant personal foul, the ball shall be put in play by any player of the free-thrower's team from the out-of-bounds spot nearest the foul.
If a free throw for a personal foul, other than intentional or flagrant, is unsuccessful, the ball remains live.
If there is a multiple throw for a personal foul(s) and the last free throw is unsuccessful, the ball remains live.
If there is a multiple throw and both a single personal and single technical foul are involved, the tries shall be attempted in the order in which the related fouls occurred.
If the last try is for a single technical foul, or intentional or flagrant personal foul, the ball shall be put in play by a throw-in.
If a false double foul involves any type of single foul and any type of double or simultaneous foul, play is resumed with the penalty for only the single foul.
The try shall be attempted from within the free-throw semicircle and behind the free-throw line.
Teams shall properly occupy marked lane spaces according to number and space requirements.
After the ball is placed at the disposal of a free thrower, the free thrower shall throw within 10 seconds to cause the ball to enter the basket or touch the ring before the free throw ends.
After the ball is placed at the disposal of a free thrower, the free thrower shall not fake a try.
After the ball is placed at the disposal of a free thrower, no player in a marked lane space shall fake to cause an opponent to violate.
No opponent shall distract the free thrower.
No player shall enter a marked lane space or leave a marked lane space by contacting the court outside the 36-inch by 36-inch space until the ball is released.

The free thrower shall not have either foot beyond the vertical plane of the edge of the free-throw line which is farther from the basket or the free-throw semicircle line until the ball touches the ring or until the free throw ends.

A player, other than the free thrower, who does not occupy a marked lane space, may not have either foot beyond the vertical plane of the free-throw line extended and the three-point line which is farther from the basket until the ball touches the ring or until the free throw ends.

A player occupying a marked lane space may not have either foot beyond the vertical plane of the outside edge of any lane boundary, or beyond the vertical plane of any edge of the space designated by lane-space marks.
A player shall position one foot near the outer edge of the free-throw lane line.
The other foot of a player occupying a marked lane space may be positioned anywhere within the designated 36-inch lane space until the ball has been released.
Players occupying marked free-throw lane lines spaces may not enter the free-throw semicircle until the ball touches the ring or until the free throw ends.
If the first or only violation is by the free thrower or a teammate, the ball becomes dead when the violation occurs, and no point can be scored by that throw.

If the violation occurs during a free throw for a personal foul, other than intentional or flagrant, the ball is awarded to the opponents for a throw-in from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.

If the violation occurs during a free throw for a technical foul, the ball is awarded to the thrower's team for a throw-in at the division line on the side of the court opposite the scorer's and timer's table.

If the violation occurs during a free throw for a flagrant personal foul or an intentional personal foul, the ball is awarded to the thrower's team for a throw-in from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the foul.
If the violation is by the free-thrower's opponent only, and if the try is successful, the goal counts and the violation is disregarded.

If the violation is by the free-thrower's opponent only, and if the try is not successful, the ball becomes dead when the free throw ends, and a substitute throw shall be attempted by the same free thrower under the same conditions as for the free throw for which it is substituted.
If there is a simultaneous violation by each team, the ball becomes dead and no point can be scored.
If the free thrower's team retains possession after a simultaneous violation, the throw-in will be at one of the four designated spots nearest the simultaneous violation.
If the opponent gains possession after a simultaneous violation, the throw-in will be at the spot nearest the simultaneous violation.
If there is a violation first by the free-thrower's opponent followed by the free thrower or a teammate, and if both offenders are in a marked lane-space, the second violation is ignored.

If there is a violation first by the free-thrower's opponent followed by the free thrower or a teammate, and if the second violation is by the free thrower or a teammate behind the free-throw line extended and/or the three-point line, both violations are penalized.
If a violation by the free thrower follows distraction by an opponent, a substitute free throw shall be awarded.
If a fake by an opponent causes the free thrower or a teammate of the free thrower to violate, only the fake is penalized.
The thrower shall not leave the designated throw-in spot until the ball has been released on a throw-in pass.
The ball shall be passed by the thrower directly into the court from out-of-bounds so it touches or is touched by another player on the court before going out of bounds untouched.
The thrown ball shall not be touched by a teammate of the thrower while the ball is on the out-of-bounds side of the throw-in boundary-line plane, except as in Rule 7-5-7.
Once the throw-in starts, the ball shall be released on a pass directly into the court before five seconds have elapsed.
The thrower shall not carry the ball onto the court.
The thrown ball shall not touch the thrower in the court before it touches or is touched by another player.
The thrown ball shall not enter the basket before it touches or is touched by another player.
The thrown ball shall not become lodged between the backboard and ring or come to rest on the flange before it touches or is touched by another player.
The thrower shall not be replaced by a teammate after the ball is at the thrower's disposal, except as in Rule 7-5-7.
The opponent(s) of the thrower shall not have any body part through the inbounds side of the throw-in boundary-line plane until the ball has been released on a throw-in pass.
The thrower may penetrate the plane provided the thrower does not touch the inbounds area or a player inbounds before the ball is released on the throw-in pass.
The opponent in this situation may legally touch or grasp the ball.
The first violation of the throw-in boundary-line plane by an opponent(s) of the thrower shall result in a team warning for delay being given.
The warning for delay does not result in the loss of the opportunity to move along the end line when and if applicable.
The second or additional violations will result in a technical foul assessed to the offending team.

If an opponent(s) reaches through the throw-in boundary-line plane and touches or dislodges the ball while in possession of the thrower or being passed to a teammate outside the boundary line, a technical foul shall be charged to the offender.
If an opponent(s) contacts the thrower, an intentional personal foul shall be charged to the offender.
No teammate of the thrower shall be out of bounds after a designated-spot throw-in begins.
The ball becomes dead when the violation or technical foul occurs after a designated-spot throw-in begins.
Following a violation after a designated-spot throw-in begins, the ball is awarded to the opponents for a throw-in at the original throw-in spot.
A player shall not cause the ball to go out of bounds.
The dribbler has committed a violation if the dribbler steps on or outside a boundary, even though the dribbler is not touching the ball while the dribbler is out of bounds.
A player shall not be out of bounds when a player touches or is touched by the ball after it has been released on a throw-in pass.
A player shall not step out of bounds under the player's own volition and then become the first player to touch the ball after returning to the playing court or to avoid a violation.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs and is awarded to the opponents for a throw-in from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
A player shall not travel with the ball, as in Rule 4-44.
A player shall not intentionally kick the ball, as in Rule 4-29.
A player shall not strike the ball with the fist or cause it to enter and pass through the basket from below.
Kicking the ball is a violation only when it is an intentional act; accidentally striking the ball with the foot or leg is not a violation.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 4.
When the opponent is awarded possession in their frontcourt, the throw-in will be at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
When the opponent is awarded possession in their backcourt, the throw-in will be from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
A player shall not dribble a second time after the player's first dribble has ended, unless it is after the player has lost control because of a try for field goal.
A player shall not dribble a second time after the player's first dribble has ended, unless it is after the player has lost control because of a touch by an opponent.

A player shall not dribble a second time after the player's first dribble has ended, unless it is after the player has lost control because of a pass or fumble which has then touched, or been touched by, another player.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 5.
When the opponent is awarded possession in their frontcourt, the throw-in will be at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
When the opponent is awarded possession in their backcourt, the throw-in will be from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
A player shall not violate any provision of the jump ball.
If both teams simultaneously commit violations during the jump ball or if the official makes a bad toss, the toss shall be repeated.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 6.
When the opponent is awarded possession in their frontcourt, the throw-in will be at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
When the opponent is awarded possession in their backcourt, the throw-in will be from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.

A player shall not remain for three seconds in that part of the player's free-throw lane between the end line and the farther edge of the free-throw line while the ball is in control of the player's team in the team's frontcourt.
The three-second restriction applies to a player who has only one foot touching the lane boundary.
Allowance shall be made for a player who, having been in the restricted area for less than three seconds, dribbles in or moves immediately to try for field goal.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 7.
The opponent is awarded a possession throw-in in its frontcourt at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
A player shall not be, nor may the player's team be, in continuous control of the ball which is in the team's backcourt for 10 seconds.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 8.
The opponent is awarded a possession throw-in in its frontcourt at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.

A player shall not be the first to touch the ball after it has been in team control in the frontcourt, if the player or a teammate last touched or was touched by the ball in the frontcourt before it went to the backcourt.

A ball in team control of Team A in the frontcourt that is deflected by a defensive player, which causes the ball to go into the backcourt, may be recovered by either team unless the offense was the last to touch the ball before it went into the backcourt.
If the offense was last to touch the ball in its frontcourt, only the defense can legally recover the basketball.

While in player and team control in its backcourt, a player shall not cause the ball to go from backcourt to frontcourt and return to backcourt, without the ball touching a player in the frontcourt, such that the player or a teammate is the first to touch it in the backcourt.

During a jump ball, throw-in or while on defense, a player may legally jump from the player's frontcourt, secure control of the ball with both feet off the floor and return to the floor with one or both feet in the backcourt.
The player may make a normal landing and it makes no difference whether the first foot down is in the frontcourt or backcourt.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 9.
The opponent is awarded a possession throw-in in its frontcourt at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
A player shall not, while closely guarded, hold the ball for five seconds or dribble the ball for five seconds in the team's frontcourt.
A player shall not, while closely guarded, control the ball for five seconds in an area enclosed by screening teammates in the team's frontcourt.
A closely guarded count shall not be started during an interrupted dribble.
A closely guarded count shall be terminated during an interrupted dribble.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 10.
The ball is awarded to the opponent for a throw-in from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation in Section 10.
A player shall not commit basket interference as in Rule 4-6.
A player shall not commit goaltending as in Rule 4-22.
If the violation is at the opponent's basket, the opponents are awarded one point if during a free throw, three points if during a three-point try and two points in any other case.

The crediting of the score and subsequent procedure are the same as if the awarded score had resulted from the ball having gone into the basket, except that the official shall hand or bounce the ball to a player of the team entitled to the throw-in.
If the violation is at a team's own basket, no points can be scored, and the ball is awarded to the opponents for a throw-in from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
If the violation results from touching the ball while it is in the basket after entering from below, no points are scored.
If the defensive team commits the violation, the opponent is awarded a possession throw-in in its frontcourt at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
If the offensive team commits the violation, the opponent is awarded a possession throw-in in its backcourt from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
If there is a violation by both teams, play shall be resumed by the team entitled to the alternating-possession throw-in.
If the offensive team retains possession, it is awarded a possession throw-in in its frontcourt at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
If the defensive team gains possession, it is awarded a possession throw-in in its backcourt from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
A player shall not excessively swing a player's own arms(s) or elbow(s), even without contacting an opponent.
A player may extend arm(s) or elbow(s) to hold the ball under the chin or against the body.

Action of arm(s) and elbow(s) resulting from total body movements as in pivoting or movement of the ball incidental to feinting with it, releasing it, or moving it to prevent a held ball or loss of control shall not be considered excessive.
The ball is dead when the violation occurs in Section 13.
When the opponent is awarded possession in its frontcourt, the throw-in will be at one of the four designated spots nearest the violation.
When the opponent is awarded possession in its backcourt, the throw-in will be from the designated out-of-bounds spot nearest the violation.
